qas.question: What do friendlies allow managers to experiment with?
What can happen to players who get red or yellow cards in friendlies?
What kind of record do players' goals in friendlies count for?
When did FIFA decide to limit substitutions in international friendlies?
What absurd number of substitutions had some international teams been making in friendlies before 2004?
What do club Friendly's give team managers a chance to experiment with?
Who can use Friendly's to assess the ability of different teams and clubs?
Who ruled that unlimited substitutions were allowed in international Friendly's?
Who was making as many as eleven substitutions per tournament?
What color cards determine whether players can participate in league games?

context: International friendlies give <b6_0>team managers<b6_0/> the opportunity to experiment with <a0_0><b5_0>team selection and tactics<b5_0/><a0_0/> before the tournament proper, and also allow them to assess the abilities of players they may potentially select for the tournament squad. Players can be booked in international friendlies, and can be <a1_0>suspended from future international matches<a1_0/> based on <b9_0>red cards or accumulated yellows<b9_0/> in a specified period. Caps and goals scored also count towards a player's <a2_0>career<a2_0/> records. In <a3_0>2004<a3_0/>, <b7_0>FIFA<b7_0/> ruled that substitutions by a team be limited to six per match in international friendlies, in response to criticism that such matches were becoming increasingly farcical with <b8_0>managers<b8_0/> making as many as <a4_0>11<a4_0/> substitutions per match.
